content.title: Great Saphenous Vein Anatomy
content.description: Detailed anatomy of the great saphenous vein, the longest superficial vein of the lower extremity and the most common site of varicose vein disease.
content.definition: The great saphenous vein (GSV) originates at the medial marginal vein of the foot, passes anterior to the medial malleolus, ascends along the medial leg and thigh in the saphenous compartment, and terminates at the saphenofemoral junction (SFJ) by joining the common femoral vein.

course: Origin: Medial marginal vein of foot dorsum
Ascends medial calf in saphenous compartment
Crosses from posterior to anterior at knee
saphenofemoral_junction: Located 2-4 cm lateral to pubic tubercle
Superficial epigastric, circumflex iliac, external pudendal veins
saphenous_compartment: Fascial compartment between muscular and saphenous fascia
GSV and saphenous nerve travel together
important_relations: Saphenous nerve: Close association below knee
Perforating veins: Multiple connections to deep system

learning_objectives: Trace GSV course from foot to SFJ
Recognize neural relationships for injury prevention
clinical_pearls: GSV is most commonly harvested conduit for bypass surgery
Saphenous nerve injury causes medial leg numbness - avoid stripping below knee
'Saphenous eye' sign on ultrasound confirms GSV in compartment
Accessory saphenous veins may be present and cause recurrence
